ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The basics of the literate brain, how the brain processes visual information and decodes words. Worked on conscience writing and summarizing/analyzing research studies.
We learned about how out brain reads both behaviorally and where it occurs physically in the brain. We also covered reading disorders and methods of treatment.
A deeper understanding of the brain and the circuits that govern spoken and written language
Understanding of brain networks in reading acquisition
I learned about reading centers in the brain

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Pugh is very engaging, even at 9am. He is always very passionate about his work and very knowledgeable. He could get off topic sometimes but loves to answer student's questions and welcomes ideas. He also is good with communication and willing to give feedback or clarify anything when needed. The material was very compelling, and you learn a lot about the reading network. Some of the research papers given were a little dense, but the more of them you read, the easier they get.
All I wish was that there had been a bit more time in the semester to do deeper dives into some of the material

Strengths: super interesting topic, papers were interesting to write and we had a lot of freedom to pick our topics
Weaknesses: lectures sometimes felt unfocused, repetitive, or tangential - sometimes difficult to focus on the material

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you have any interest in the brain TAKE THIS CLASS. I learned so many cool things about the brain and language.

Yes and no. Professor Pugh is super great and you can tell he is really passionate about his work. I really admire him for that. That being said, the class is pretty uninteresting at times, unless you're looking to go directly into this field. Professor Pugh goes on long tangents and most of his slides are pretty unhelpful. It's basically like he's just talking without slides. That being said again, you don't really need to know any of the information he is talking about in class to do well. So, even if you just sit in the class doing other things and not taking notes, you will do well if you complete the assignments well. All in all though, Professor Pugh is a great professor to know. He is kind and understanding. I would really only recommend this class to someone interested into going into the field.
I would recommend the course to other students. There are a lot interesting topics covered in this course.
Absolutely. It is intellectually challenging without being overwhelming, and it will forever change the way you view reading and the human mind.
Yes! It's a pretty chill class with a great professor where you can learn a lot. It's nice to take a focused class like this where you really dive into the topic

Yes, if youre really interested in the topic. You have to be pretty self motivated - keeping up with readings, choosing paper topics, and paying attention in class is really all on you, but if you want to, youll learn a lot.

extras.title: LING 233 01/LING 633 01 - The Literate Brain and Mind
